Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 16 Sep 2018 cyber security researchers reported that school computer systems within a Florida Keys school district had been taken offline for at least three days following a ransomware attack involving a new variant of GandCrab. A school district employee discovered a problem with the IT system on 09 Sep 2018 and on advice from Symantec the school took their system offline. Symantec subsequently created a patch for the school's system. No ransom was paid and the school district was able to recover its files from a backup copy unaffected from the ransomware. The ransomware did not disrupt employee data, although it did affect the delivery of students' mid-quarter progress reports. No further information was available at the time of writing regarding the new variant of GandCrab.

Assessment: GandCrab has emerged as a widely distributed and highly active ransomware variant during 2018 and has recently targeted users in both South Korean (see incident 42535356) and the Middle East (see incident 44295485). It is widely sold on criminal forums, making attribution difficult, and Symantec's identification of it as a new variant highlights how it is easily modified and used by threat actors. It is therefore highly likely that GandCrab will continue to target a variety of sectors and geographies.

Schools and other public targets such as hospitals are typically seen as attractive targets for ransomware, due to the perception by threat actors that public pressure will induce them to pay any ransom demand; however, the lack of disruption to data such as employee payroll indicates that in this instance GandCrab only affected limited local networks. The ransomware only caused minimal disruption to the Florida school district and no ransom was paid, due to the relevant files being backed up, highlighting the importance of organizations keeping a second copy of their files secure as part of any mitigation strategy.

Source evaluation: CSO Online is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.

Additional sources

hxxps://www[.]scmagazine[.]com/home/news/new-gandcrab-variant-attacks-florida-school-district/
Tip_Reports.name: New GandCrab ransomware linked to attack on Florida Keys school district (Digital Shadows Id: 44567033)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 14 Sep 2018, Bleeping Computer reported a new malvertising. campaign in which the Fallout exploit kit was distributing a new ransomware variant, dubbed SAVEfiles, to targets predominantly in Japan and France.

The malvertising campaign caused multiple redirects that finally directing the user to a domain hosting the Fallout exploit kit. Fallout then exploited vulnerabilities in VBScript and Flash player (CVE-2018-8174) to automatically initiate the download of SAVEfiles onto the compromised computer. SAVEfiles then encrypted the contents and created a ransom demand in each encrypted folder issuing the user with an allegedly unique identification number and providing instructions for the user to contact the threat actor responsible, via email, for payment information. No cryptocurrency wallet address or ransom amount were given; however, threat actors promised 50% if they were contacted within 72 hours. Additional details were unavailable at the time of writing.

Assessment: The recent deployment of ransomware variants (see incident 44295485) in malvertising campaign indicates an increase in Fallout's capabilities and targeting. Currently, Fallout is assessed to have moderate capabilities due to an uptake in deployable malware variants but an unsophisticated target exploit. Although Fallout continues to exploit the same vulnerabilities, threat developers will likely modify its entry vector to target additional exploits in the near future to remain competitive. Given the persistent change in its capabilities, and the persistence of use in ongoing campaigns, Fallout will likely continue to increase in popularity in the near future (within three months).

Additional details on the threat actor responsible for this malvertising campaign or the author of SAVEfiles was unavailable. SAVEfiles was assessed to be unsophisticated and relied upon Fallout’s automated download and network communication capabilities to attain its encryption standard. The use of a personal ID and the need to interact with the threat actor likely indicates a low level campaign. The tactic of offering money off for early replies is typically used by threat actors deploying ransomware, as they believe that pressure to pay for a reduced amount is likely to encourage victims to concede to demands.

Source Evaluation: Bleeping computer was unable to be assessed at the time of writing, however, information contained within followed industry patterns and was likely true.
Tip_Reports.name: Fallout exploit kit observed distributing SAVEfiles ransomware (Digital Shadows Id: 44484594)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

The Kraken Cryptor ransomware has been observed masquerading as a legitimate SuperAntiSpyware anti-malware program hosted on the official download site (superantispyware[.]com). The malicious download was hosted alongside the legitimate version, and had a similar filename in an attempt to trick users. It was unconfirmed at the time of writing how the attackers accessed the SuperAntiSpyware website, nor how users were directed to the malicious download since the links on the site all redirected to the legitimate version.

The encryption and extortion process demonstrated by Kraken Cryptor is relatively standard in comparison to other ransomware variants. The download includes an embedded configuration file which contains a predetermined list of modules which, if enabled, conducts the encryption process by identifying suitable files to target. The language and location of the device is checked, with some Eastern European and other countries exempt from attacks. Each eligible file is appended with a “-Lock.onion” extension.

Assessment: Compromise of a legitimate website and impersonation of an anti-malware executable is a relatively sophisticated technique for ransomware distribution. There was no indication users had downloaded the malicious Krakon Cryptor file, since all download links on the site directed to the legitimate version. This could potentially indicate the ransomware was discovered during the early setup stages of the attack; the ransomware executable has since been removed from the site. The exemption list of geographies provides some insight in to Krakon Cryptor’s targeting, but attribution is unknown. The most effective mitigation for a ransomware attack is to ensure all files are backed up, enabling recovery without having to submit to extortion demands.

Assessment: Bleeping Computer is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.
Tip_Reports.name: Ransomware attempts to impersonate anti-malware downloadable (Digital Shadows Id: 44481041)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

A new malware variant called “Xbash” which combines botnet, mining, ransomware and self-propagating capabilities has been identified by cyber security researchers. It can target both Linux and Microsoft Windows servers, and has been associated “Iron” (aka “Rocke”), a threat group which has previously been attributed with ransomware attacks, given similarities with previous malware developed by the group. The botnet capabilities are believed to have been active since May 2018.

Although Xbash has self-propagating capabilities these appear to be currently inactive. If implemented, the malware could spread quickly within an organization’s network by targeting weak passwords and unpatched vulnerabilities. Xbash seemingly destroys data rather than encrypting it, but includes an extortion demand as part of its attack in order to appear like a ransomware threat. Forty-eight payments have been made to associated cryptocurrency wallets to date, equating to USD 6,000. However, there does not appear to be a data restoration component, indicating the intent is likely destruction and disruption as well as financial gain.

Assessment: Palo Alto have detected four versions of Xbash to date, all of which have appeared to be under development. There were several components which were inactive, including the self-propagation capability mentioned above, and an intranet scanning function which aimed to identify vulnerable devices within enterprise intranet. The multi-functionality of the malware makes it a lucrative prospect for various types of attacks; there was no indication it was being offered as a crimeware-as-a-service, but could present the Iron group a profitable option in future. Its development could indicate that the group are expanding or strengthening their capabilities. Reporting did not specify if a specific geography or industry sector was being targeted to date.

Because Xbash targets passwords and vulnerabilities, users are advised to ensure credentials are strong and unique, and to apply security patches and updates in a timely manner.

Source evaluation: Palo Alto is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.
Tip_Reports.name: New multi-function malware targets Linux and Windows devices (Digital Shadows Id: 44596993)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 10 Sep 2018 the Italian National Institute for Social Assistance (INAS) reported that its Web portal had been the victim of a cyber attack. Attackers exfiltrated sensitive information on approximately 37,000 individuals including user email addresses, passwords, telephone numbers and profession details. No further technical details were available regarding the breach at the time of writing; the incident has since been reported to the Italian Data Protection Authority and law enforcement.

Assessment: Although no technical details, or details regarding the attackers had been released to date, INAS' press release indicated that it was the victim of a data breach attack, rather than a threat actor taking advantage of exposed data. PII is easily monetized on the dark Web, and used for fraud, spam campaigns, and as spearphishing lures. Although Digital Shadows has detected no malicious activity regarding this information as yet, such attacks attempting to exploit this data should be considered likely in the next six months.

Source evaluation: There was insufficient reporting to assess the reliability of INAS, the information provided was possibly true.
Tip_Reports.name: Italian National Institute for Social Assistance suffers data breach (Digital Shadows Id: 44532829)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 17 Sep 2018, Bristol Airport in the United Kingdom was reportedly affected by an unnamed ransomware variant which caused disruption to the display of flight information throughout the airport. The attack reportedly did not delay any flights; airport officials were relegated to using whiteboards and paper to display flight information throughout the 14th and 15th of September. Airport officials claimed that they did not intend to pay any ransom being demanded by the malware. Systems were reportedly fully restored as of 16 Sep 2018.

Assessment: Though the specific ransomware variant was not identified, this incident highlights the disruptive effects that ransomware can cause within an airport environment. There was a limited amount of information regarding this incident, though reports indicated that no flight delays resulted from the ransomware attack. This would suggest the malware affected a separate system which was not directly responsible for handling flight data, but rather displaying customer flight information. As such, the overall assessment of this incident was deemed to be Very Low due to the limited amount of damage, reputational or otherwise, caused to the Bristol Airport.

Source Evaluation: BBC is considered a usually reliable and accurate source of information.
Tip_Reports.name: Ransomware minimally affects UK airport (Digital Shadows Id: 44583729)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In August 2018, the Brazilian cryptocurrency investment platform Atlas Quantum suffered a data breach. The breach leaked the personal data of 261k investors on the platform including their names, phone numbers, email addresses and account balances. According to Atlas, customer funds were not affected by the breach. Please note, the email address affected by this breach were sourced from HaveIBeenPwned; as a result, Digital Shadows does not have the associated personal information which was also reportedly exposed.

The data contains 261463 rows of data with no passwords.

The data is displayed in the following format: email address

In approximately February 2015, the home financing website MyFHA suffered a data breach which disclosed the personal information of nearly 1 million people. The data included extensive personal information relating to home financing including personal contact info, credit statuses, household incomes, loan amounts and notes on personal circumstances, often referring to legal issues, divorces and health conditions. Multiple parties contacted HIBP with the data after which MyFHA was alerted in mid-July and acknowledged the legitimacy of the breach then took the site offline.

The data contains 972629 rows of data with no passwords.

On 12 Jun 2018 researchers identified a server associated with the Trik botnet hosting 43 million email addresses. These emails likely formed spam email lists, which threat actors can target to distribute malware, or conduct other malicious activity. Of the discovered email addresses, there were reportedly 4.6 million unique email domains from various services including .gov domains or small enterprises. There were 18.9 million emails exposed from AOL and Yahoo services. The data was uploaded to website Have I been Pwned, and contained 43432346 rows of data with no passwords.

The Trik botnet, according to recent research by Proofpoint has been active for a decade, and is likely used by various malware operators as a spam email distribution mechanism (Incident: 34336507). It was recently associated with the distribution of the GandCrab ransomware, and will likely remain active.

Assessment: Many of the emails were from older email services like AOL and Yahoo, indicating that some affected emails were likely compiled from previous breaches, as well as reflecting the age of the Trik botnet. In addition to leveraging previous breaches, threat actors could have conducted scraping of open source websites to obtain email addresses. The email addresses contained in this breach will likely continue to be exposed to spam emails from various malware campaigns, or other malicious activity like brute force cracking attempts or social engineering. Affected users are advised to use strong passwords, multi-factor authentication and remain aware of spam and social engineering campaigns.

Source evaluation: HIBP and Bleeping Computer are usually reliable, the information was probably true.
hxxps://www[.]bleepingcomputer[.]com/news/security/trik-spam-botnet-leaks-43-million-email-addresses/

In October 2017, the blog commenting service Disqus announced they'd suffered a data breach. The breach dated back to July 2012 but wasn't identified until years later when the data finally surfaced. The breach contained over 17.5 million unique email addresses and usernames. Users who created logins on Disqus had salted SHA1 hashes of passwords whilst users who logged in via social providers only had references to those accounts.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident doesn't display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for users of the Disqus service.
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from disqus[.]com. (Digital Shadows Id: 23635561)

In January 2014, the online service for assisting musicians to build their careers ReverbNation suffered a data breach which wasn't identified until September the following year. The breach contained over 7 million accounts with unique email addresses and salted SHA1 passwords.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident does not display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.

Incident severity reflects that the breach was announced over 24 months ago.

In July 2016, a hacker known as Phineas Fisher hacked Turkey's ruling party (Justice and Development Party or "AKP") and gained access to 300k emails. The full contents of the emails were subsequently published by WikiLeaks and made searchable. Have I Been Pwned identified over 917461 unique email address patterns in the data set, including message IDs and a number of other non-user addresses.

Please note, this data set did not include passwords according to the Have I Been Pwned site therefore incident severity has been reduced.

In May 2017, font sharing site DaFont suffered a data breach resulting in the exposure of 637k records. Allegedly due to a SQL injection vulnerability exploited by multiple parties, the exposed data included usernames, email addresses and passwords stored as MD5 without a salt.

The information was added to an unknown website, on an unknown date, with an unknown title and was uploaded by an unknown user.

In December 2016, more than 200 million data enrichment profiles were found for sale on the darknet. The seller claimed the data was sourced from Experian and whilst that claim was rejected by the company, the data itself was found to be legitimate suggesting it may have been sourced from other legitimate locations. In total, there were more than 8 million unique email addresses in the data which also contained a raft of other personal attributes including credit ratings, home ownership status, family structure and other fields described in the story linked to above.

The email addresses alone were provided to HIBP.

On 05 May 2017, Troy Hunt confirmed the upload of 1,051,389,657 records for compromised accounts into the Have I Been Pwned (HIBP) database. These additions have resulted in a 39 percent increase in the total HIBP database. The newly uploaded data was reportedly sourced from two different “combo lists”, which were an amalgamation of data sourced from numerous different locations rather than one large, singular data breach.

One of the lists has been dubbed “Anti-Public”, and contained 457,962,538 unique email addresses. This list has reportedly previously been widely circulated and used for credential stuffing attacks, whereby attackers seek to identify instances of password reuse in order to compromise further accounts. “Anti-Public” is also the name of a credential stuffing tool used to verify the legitimacy of compromised credentials. The tool is offered for sale on criminal forums and marketplaces in Russian and English formats. It reportedly works similarly to SentryMBA, using an automated process to test credential combinations.

Digital Shadows was already in possession of the second combo list, dubbed “Exploit[.]in”, and has raised it to impacted clients on 11 Sep 2016. This list is a combination of 111 text files totalling over 24GB. The content is similar to the Anti-Public list; a mixture of email addresses and plain-text password combinations including 593,427,119 unique email addresses.
Tip_Reports.name: Anti Public Combo List (Digital Shadows Id: 18468506)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In March 2017, the telemarketing service Health Now Networks left a database containing hundreds of thousands of medical records exposed. There were over 900,000 records in total containing significant volumes of personal information including names, dates of birth, various medical conditions and operator notes on the individuals' health. The data included over 320k unique email addresses.

Please note the details were gained from haveibeenpwned[.]com and therefore do not have corresponding passwords. However, we assess it is highly likely these credentials have been compromised.

In approximately late 2015, the maker of "performance marketing products" QuinStreet had a number of their online assets compromised. The attack impacted 28 separate sites, predominantly technology forums such as flashkit.com, codeguru.com and webdeveloper.com (view a full list of sites). QuinStreet advised that impacted users have been notified and passwords reset. The data contained details on over 4.9 million people and included email addresses, dates of birth and salted MD5 hashes.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident doesn't display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.

In August 2016, the technology recruitment site GeekedIn left a MongoDB database exposed and over 8M records were extracted by an unknown third party. The breached data was originally scraped from GitHub in violation of their terms of use and contained information exposed in public profiles, including over 1 million members' email addresses.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident doesn't display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.

View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In mid to late 2015, a spam list known as the Special K Data Feed was discovered containing almost 31M identities. The data includes personal attributes such as names, physical and IP addresses, genders, birth dates and phone numbers.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident doesn't display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from data4marketers.com (Digital Shadows Id: 14442164)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In late 2011, data was allegedly obtained from the Chinese website known as Dodonew.com and contained 8.7M accounts. Whilst there is evidence that the data is legitimate, due to the difficulty of emphatically verifying the Chinese breach it has been flagged as "unverified". The data in the breach contains email addresses and user names.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident doesn't display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from dodonew.com (Digital Shadows Id: 14441581)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

A post was added to raidforums[.]com on 27 Oct 2016 under the title "ForumFree[.]it" and uploaded by user "2ndday".

The post contains rows of user IDs, emails and associated passwords in hashed format claimed to have been sourced from ForumFree[.]it.

The data is displayed in the following format:
IDs: emails: associated passwords
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from forumfree[.]it (Digital Shadows Id: 12865236)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In July 2016, a tweet was posted with a link to an alleged data breach of BlueSnap, a global payment gateway and merchant account provider. The data contained 324k payment records across 105k unique email addresses and included personal attributes such as name, home address and phone number. The data was verified with multiple Have I been pwned subscribers who confirmed it also contained valid transactions, partial credit card numbers, expiry dates and CVVs. A downstream consumer of BlueSnap services known as Regpack was subsequently identified as the source of the data after they identified human error had left the transactions exposed on a publicly facing server. A full investigation of the data and statement by Regpack is detailed in the post titled Someone just lost 324k payment records, complete with CVVs.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident does not display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from bluesnap.com (Digital Shadows Id: 12416925)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In September 2016, the paid-to-click site ClixSense suffered a data breach which exposed 2.4 million subscriber identities. The breached data was then posted online by the attackers who claimed it was a subset of a larger data breach totalling 6.6 million records. The leaked data was extensive and included names, physical, email and IP addresses, genders and birth dates, account balances and passwords stored as plain text.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident does not display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from ClixSense (Digital Shadows Id: 12416919)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In November 2015, the forum software maker vBulletin suffered a serious data breach. The attack lead to the release of both forum user and customer accounts totalling almost 519k records. The breach included email addresses, birth dates, security questions and answers for customers and salted hashes of passwords for both sources.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident does not display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from vBulletin (Digital Shadows Id: 12416908)

Tip_Reports.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

In October 2011, the Android Forums website was hacked and 745k user accounts were subsequently leaked publicly. The compromised data included email addresses, user birth dates and passwords stored as a salted MD5 hash.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident does not display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.
Tip_Reports.name: Report of data leak from Android Forums (Digital Shadows Id: 12416907)
